tossups.question: 1. Repeated attempts by members of this ethnicity to flee persecution helped necessitate the closure of the Torugart Pass. Nationalists of this ethnicity took advantage of a civil war to proclaim an autonomous government named for the mythic man Alash. They’re not Ukrainians, but 1.3 million members of this ethnic group died in the so-called “Goloschkein” famine from 1932 to 1933. These people took to the streets in December 1986 after the sacking of a General Secretary of this ethnicity and his replacement with an ethnic (*) Russian; those riots were called Jeltoqsan. People of this ethnicity were the main victims of fallout from the Semipalatinsk test site. The Soviet Socialist Republic named for this ethnic group is where Trofim Lysenko enacted the Virgin Lands Campaign. Nursultan Nazarbayev belongs to, for 10 points, what ethnic group whose namesake republic once had its capital in Almaty?
tossups.answer: Kazakhs <WA, World History>

tossups.question: 2. One of these animals tries to bite the arm of an angel in his path as he “gallops about doing good” in a poem by Stevie Smith. Another poem claims these animals can “spraggle upon waggle” and ends “For he can swim for life. For he can creep.” That list-formatted poem by Christopher Smart is about Jeoffry. Another poem about one of these animals is set near a vase which “China’s gayest art had dyed” with “azure flowers” and laments “No dolphin came, no Nereid stirred” to its aid. That poem originated the phrase “Nor all that (*) glisters, gold.” Another series of poems about these animals claims that they must have “three different names” and include the conjuring Mr. Mistoffelees and the criminal Macavity. Those poems are from T. S. Eliot’s “Old Possum’s Book of” these Practical” animals. For 10 points, Thomas Gray wrote about the drowning of what pet Selima in a tub of goldfish?
tossups.answer: cat <JC, Poetry>

tossups.question: 3. This politician’s actions on LGBT rights include signing an Insurance Equality Act guaranteeing coverage for same-sex partners and an expansion of the Unruh Rights Act, the latter on the same day as his veto of a same-sex marriage bill. Marsy’s Law, enacted during this politician’s tenure as governor, provided grounds for the family of Louis Santos to sue his administration after the sentence of Esteban Nuñez was commuted. While campaigning, this man was criticized for meeting with Enron executives at the Peninsula Hotel after his predecessor suffered a massive drop in popularity due to (*) blackouts caused in part by Enron’s fraud. This politician, who admitted to an affair with Mildred Patricia Baena, his housekeeper, was elected as governor in a recall election that ousted Gray Davis. For 10 points, name this Governor of California from 2003 to 2011 and star of the Terminator series.
tossups.answer: Arnold Schwarzenegger [accept either underlined portion; accept Ahnuld] <WA, US History>

tossups.question: 4. Carl Ernst posited that this text uses a form of symmetrical arrangement between the beginning and end called “ring composition.” The density of literary devices in this text is often used as an argument for its literary inimitability, which is commonly stated as a challenge to produce a “chapter like it.” In a book titled this work “in context,” Angelika Neuwirth suggests that it be considered as a product of Late Antiquity. A commentary titled for being “In the Shade of” this other text was written while the author was (*) imprisoned for an assassination attempt; that commentary, along with the book Milestones, serves as a manifesto for Qutbism. A section of this text talking about three daughters of God was later edited out and formed the basis of a Salman Rushdie novel. For 10 points, name this book that once contained the “Satanic Verses” and is divided into 114 chapters called surahs.
tossups.answer: al-Qur’an [or Koran] <EM, Literary Legacy>

tossups.question: 5. Re-interpretation of texts written under this empire’s rule was the primary goal of Matthew Restall and James Lockhart, members of the New Philology movement. Alexander Hill Everett used his diplomatic post to send documents about this empire’s history to his friend William Scott Prescott for use in his three books on it. The term for a process begun by this empire’s foreign forays was coined by the title of a 1972 book by Alfred Crosby, the author of Ecological Imperialism. A “political essay” on this empire’s holdings was written by (*) Alexander von Humboldt. Within this empire’s caste system, “peninsular” people were given the most privileges. Supposedly unrivaled cruelty by this empire was the subject of the “Black Legend,” furthered by sympathetic priests who translated native documents like the Florentine Codex. For 10 points, name this empire which conquered the Aztecs.
tossups.answer: Spanish empire [or Spain or Spanish Bourbon empire or Hapsburg empire; prompt on Holy Roman Empire; prompt on Bourbon empire; do not accept or prompt on “Austrian empire” or “Austria”] <WA, Historiography>

tossups.question: 6. In the 77th year of this century, the Great Council of Ragusa determined European quarantining to be a period of thirty days. Sir Michael Postan’s thesis argues that demographic trends in the century before this one contributed to this century’s “Malthusian crisis.” The Sack of Limoges and the First Castilian Civil War are described in a primary source recounting this century. This century is labeled “calamitous” in the subtitle of (*) Barbara Tuchman’s A Distant Mirror. The fifteenth through seventeenth years of this century witnessed a general population collapse throughout Europe due to a Great Famine chronicled by Jean Froissart, in contrast to the extensive population growth of the prior centuries. In this century, increasing tax burdens and passage of acts like the Statute of Laborers led to uprisings like France’s Jacquerie and England’s Peasants’ Revolt. For 10 points, identify this century in which the Black Death wiped out a third of Europe’s population.
tossups.answer: 14th century CE [or 14th century AD; or 1300s CE; or 1300s AD] <AA, Continental History>

tossups.question: 7. The voice of one of these objects is possessed by a “half-bodied baby” that rises from ashes after it is killed by Tutuola’s palm-wine drinkard and his wife. In a novel named for one of these physical objects, the protagonist is told that Gone with the Wind is a documentary, and her mother slips messages like “America is cruel. Consider kindness” into the linens she delivers. In that work, “the Watchman” yells prophecies during a fire after killing his employers and Paul H. with a machete. Jim and Abby rather notably use one of these devices in (*) Nicholson Baker’s Vox. Clare Savage is killed in a guerilla resistance in Michelle Cliff’s sequel to Abeng named for “No” [one of these objects] “To Heaven.” For 10 points, John O’Hara’s BUtterfield 8 is named after a code used for what devices, which are referenced in the title of Dial M for Murder?
tossups.answer: telephones <JC, LongFic>

tossups.question: 8. In a story by this author, a disoriented new immigrant from Bombay moves to D.C. and finds himself annoyed by the “bad sanskrit” of the white Hare Krishnas in his neighborhood. That character, Santosh, later marries the “hubshi” woman who takes care of his apartment. Dayo is driven out of operating his roti-shop after moving to England in another of this author’s stories. This author of “One Out of Many” and “Tell Me Who To Kill” wrote a story in which a (*) Zulu man spits on Linda’s husband, Bobby, after he flirts with him while traveling through a fictional African country. Man Man and Bogart are two characters who frequently appear in a collection by this author titled for a neighborhood in Port of Spain, where he also set a novel about a man who desires to please his Tulsi in-laws with the title structure. For 10 points name this author of “In a Free State,” Miguel Street, and A House for Mr. Biswas.
tossups.answer: V. S. Naipaul <SB, Short Fiction>

tossups.question: 9. Note to players: Type of work and author required. One of these works complains about “that second-hand school of poetry” in the context of discussing reviews by Blackwood’s Edinburgh Magazine. Some of these works boast of “hundreds” of “pl & opt Cs,” a shorthand the author borrowed from the Satyricon to refer to sex, such as in the context of Nicolo Giraud. Another of these works lambasts “Turdsworth,” echoing a criticism that their author made of Wordsworth and Robert Southey in Canto I of a poem. One of these works is burned in front of Lady Croom by (*) Septimus Hodge in Tom Stoppard’s Arcadia. Many of these works are addressed to Teresa, Contessa Guiccioli [ghee-CHOH-lee], the author’s lover in Ravenna, and many others are to Percy Shelley. One of them says “If I am a poet… the air of Greece has made me one.” For 10 points, identify these epistles by the author of “Manfred” and “Don Juan.”
tossups.answer: letters by Lord Byron <WA, Authors/Bios>

tossups.question: 10. At the end of this play’s second act, a character vows to prove to his wife “how far [he is] from jealousy or fear.” Two characters in this play discuss the legend of a townsman named Mass Stone, who supposedly worked as a spy and smuggled secrets written on cabbages out of the Netherlands. A servant in this play explains that he abandoned his vow of silence because the spirit of a lawyer had possessed him. An acrostic poem that spells out the name of the title character appears in this play’s (*) “Argument,” which comes before its prologue. The title character of this play disguises himself as the Scoto Mantua and sings a song praising his fake potion in front of Sir Politic Would Be. Nano and Castrone are two servants of this play's title character, who listens to Mosca and spurns prostitutes to pursue the beautiful Celia. For 10 points, name this play about a rich fox-like Venetian by Ben Jonson.
tossups.answer: Volpone <SB, Drama>

tossups.question: 11. Hellenistic Greeks created varieties of these objects called thureoi that copied Celtic designs. After the Battle of Gabiene, an elite group named for examples of these objects handed over their commander Eumenes to Antigonus the One-Eyed in exchange for their baggage train. Plutarch records that the phrase “Ē tān ē epi tas,” which refers to these items, was spoken to departing men in (*) Sparta by their wives. An iconic example of these items from Classical Greece was called the aspis, with a specific variety being called a hoplon. An example of this item called a scutum was carried by Roman legionaries, who would use it to form a testudo or “tortoise” formation. For 10 points, name these typically wooden objects used by soldiers to protect themselves in battle.
tossups.answer: shields [accept Silver Shields; accept aspis or hoplon before they are read; accept “with this shield or on it] <WA, Ancient History> Note to moderator: Read the answerline carefully before starting.

tossups.question: 12. One of these institutions dealt with the issue of “separating hard and white.” These institutions refined the original methods of “correlative thinking.” Lewis Maverick wrote that the Physiocrats modeled themselves on one of these institutions, which contended that the man who introduced “five cereals” for cultivation was the ideal king. In a story from one of these institutions, kings needing to sate people’s conflicting desires is the origin of rituals. One of these institutions that promulgated such ideas as “a white horse is not a horse” was named after (*) “names.” The so-called “Golden Age of Chinese Philosophy” is known as the “contention” of one hundred of these institutions. For 10 points, name these institutions, of which only a few outside of Legalism survived when Qin Shi Huangdi initiated the “burning of books and killing of scholars.”
tossups.answer: The Hundred Schools of Thought from the Zhou Dynasty/Warring States Period [or zhūzǐ bǎijiā; accept nine schools of thought; accept schools (of thought) in ancient China; accept schools during the Han Dynasty; accept schools during the Qin Dynasty; accept schools during the Warring States Period; accept schools during the Zhou Dynasty; prompt on schools by asking “during what era?” and expect one of the aforementioned answers; prompt on Chinese philosophies or similar such answers before mention of “Chinese Philosophy”; prompt on any answer suggesting a philosophical movement] <AA, Phil/SS>

tossups.question: 13. A leader of this country wrote a violently racist essay in which he denounced Chinese as the “Jews of the East.” Cultivation of cane sugar and rubber were both introduced to this country in the early 19th century by Chinese immigrants, especially Teochews, who were said to rise from “mat to riches.” Chinese people in this country created the markets of Sampheng and invented the drink that became Red Bull. The lands of this modern-day country were unified by a (*) general of Chinese birth named Taksin. Thanks to extensive immigration and assimilation, this non-U.S. country has the largest Overseas Chinese population in the world, and Chinese are estimated to control 90 percent of its corporations. For 10 points, name this country whose leaders of Chinese ancestry have included the Shinawatras, who were overthrown in coups in Bangkok.
tossups.answer: Kingdom of Thailand [or Kingdom of Siam; accept any answer referring to the Thai people or Thai kingdom] <WA, World History>

tossups.question: 14. A female author from this country broke taboos by openly depicting female desire in her novel Love in Excess. The play Almyna exemplifies dramatic forms of a genre pioneered by female authors in this country called “amatory fiction.” Seventy-two years of diaries, the first of which is addressed to “Nobody,” were kept by a female author from this country. A female author from here created a heroine who discovers a human figure made of wax behind a black veil and is helped by the servant (*) Ludovico, who works for a bandit nobleman. An author from this country created such villains as Schedoni [skeh-DOH-nee] and Montoni, the latter of whom owns the title castle investigated by Emily St. Aubert. For 10 points, name this home country of Eliza Haywood, Frances Burney, and Mysteries of Udolpho author Ann Radcliffe.
tossups.answer: England [or Great Britain or the United Kingdom or UK] <WA, LongFic>

tossups.question: 15. In one work named after this figure, Marcellus attempts to stab this man in the back but is suddenly unable to, and kills himself in remorse. In that play, this man watches as his wife is poisoned with a peach, and he accumulates followers who chant “Death is dead!” and continually perform the title action. A poem named after this figure lists “A cake of soap / A wedding ring / A gold filling” and asks “Peel off the napkin… Do I terrify?” (*) Sonya reads a passage about this man to Raskolnikov in Crime and Punishment. This figure, who “Laughed” in a Eugene O’Neill drama, titles a poem that states “Dying / is an art, like everything else” and concludes “Beware. / Out of the ash / I rise with my red hair / and I eat men like air.” That poem by Sylvia Plath is named after “Lady” [this character]. For 10 points, name this Biblical figure from Bethany whom Jesus resurrects.
tossups.answer: Lazarus <JC, Miscellaneous Lit>

tossups.question: 16. In an essay, this author divided novelists into two “camps,” the preachers and teachers, headed by Tolstoy and Dickens, and the pure artists, headed by Austen and Turgenev, and described how E. M. Forster attempted to straddle both camps. In another essay, this author wrote about the death of a creature that looked as “if someone had taken a tiny bead of pure life” and “had set it dancing and zig zagging to show us the true nature of life.” This author compiled three essays about Henry (*) James into one collection, whose title essay is about an insect that admits “death is stronger than I am.” An essay by this author of “Death of the Moth” was written for her “Women and Fiction” lectures and includes a section on Judith Shakespeare. For 10 points name this author of "A Room of One's Own."
tossups.answer: Virginia Woolf <SB, Essays/Crit>

tossups.question: 17. This organization’s adoption of violent guerrilla tactics caused a split with other organizations in the Autonomist movement, which the government still targeted for arrest. People accused of supporting this organization who fled to France were protected from extradition under the “Mitterrand doctrine,” such as an intellectual who later published the books Commonwealth and Multitude. It’s not a political party, but a “Front of Firmness” opposing this group was maintained by ideological allies of it who had accepted the Historic Compromise, such as (*) Enrico Berlinguer. This was the main left-wing group behind violent acts that exemplified the “strategy of tension” during the 1970s and 1980s, such as when it killed the leader of the Christian Democrat party at the height of the Years of Lead. For 10 points, name this terrorist group that kidnapped Aldo Moro, the Prime Minister of Italy.
tossups.answer: Red Brigades [or Brigate Rossi] <WA, Continental History>

tossups.question: 18. During an incident on this island, wounded soldiers ate lettuce while whispering “run, rabbit, run” as a form of dissent. Ken G. Hall won an Academy Award for his film about military action on this island, which he sourced from newsreels taken by Damien Parer. Sydney Rowell and Arthur Allen were dismissed during a campaign on this island conducted by the Maroubra Force. The Dobodura base on this island was used to scramble planes to defend from aerial assaults in Operation I-Go. Soldiers on one side of a campaign on this island were assisted by natives called the (*) “Fuzzy-Wuzzy Angels.” Control of this island’s Owen Stanley Range was contested during the Kokoda Track Campaign, which, like the Battle of the Coral Sea, sought to prevent Japanese control of Port Moresby. For 10 points, name this island also known as Papua.
tossups.answer: New Guinea [or Niugini or Irian Jaya; accept Papua until “Papua” is read] <EM, British/Other History>

tossups.question: 19. In one work, a story is told about a character who spared this man’s life when he fainted, only for this man to fail to spare him in return; that work describes this man sitting on a log ordering men to cross a river and not watching as they drown. An author who poked fun at “The Second Funeral” of this man also created a woman who profits from selling her horse at inflated prices to Joseph Sedley during a panic caused by his actions. A would-be Freemason symbolically proves this man is the (*) Antichrist and tries to assassinate him in a novel that uses him as an instance of a historical “great man.” Dostoevsky’s Raskolnikov claims that he wants to become like this man, whom Pierre Bezukhov seeks to kill. For 10 points, name this Frenchman who is fought at Borodino in the novel War and Peace.
tossups.answer: Napoleon Bonaparte [accept either name; or Napoleon I; or Napoleone di Buonaparte] <JC, HistInLit>

tossups.question: 20. A work made of this material containing several “admonitions” addressed to the Lord of All is of interest to Biblical scholars for noting that a river is made of blood. Karl Lepsius probably illegally acquired an object made of this material that depicts five stories of priests and magicians. A fragmented object made of this material drew controversy in 2012 for claiming to depict Jesus’ wife, but is likely a forgery. Examples of this material used to record medical practices were collected by (*) George Ebers and Edwin Smith. A work made of this material called “Westcar” covers the reigns of Sneferu and Khufu. This material was made of strips of Cyperus that may have been glued together, and generally preserved well in dry climes like Egypt. For 10 points, name this ancient writing material, the name of which gives English its word “paper.”
tossups.answer: papyrus [or papyri; do not accept or prompt on “paper”] <WA, Historical Sources>

tossups.question: 21. In August 2017, more than 50 acres of Roman ruins were found off the coast of this country near the town of Nabeul. A mosaic found in this non-China country from the 4th century AD depicting Dominus Julius and his estate is in its Bardo Museum. A huge amphitheater that could hold 35,000 people can be seen in the ruins of Thysdrus in this country. The presidential palace of this country is found near the Baths of Antoninus Pius. A 2013 paper by Paolo Xella et al. argued that (*) child cemeteries found in this country contained the victims of sacrifices at tophets. Stones taken from ruins in this country were used to build additions to the Great Mosque of Kairouan. This country contains the ruins of Utica, which served as the capital of the Roman province of Africa. For 10 points, name this North African country which contains the ruins of Carthage.
tossups.answer: (Republic of) Tunisia <WA, Archaeology>

tossups.question: 22. This poem’s speaker cannot remember if he made plans with Phyllis “who had two dimples in her cheeks,” on Christopher Street ten years ago. The speaker of this poem tells its addressee that he has forgotten her name and goes on to list possible names, including “Melusina, Laura, Isabel, Persephone,” and “Mary.” The epigraph to this poem quotes the opening lines of Gerard de Nerval’s poem “Artemis.” An abruptly short line in this poem consists only of the words “Madrid, (*) 1937.” This poem frequently repeats variations of the line “I go amongst your body as among the world” and it begins and ends with the same six lines, which reference a river that “doubles back, and comes full circle.” Its 584 lines are meant to mirror the number of days in Venus’s synodic orbit. For 10 points, name this poem which begins describing a “willow of crystal, a poplar of water,” written by Octavio Paz.
tossups.answer: “Sunstone” [or “Piedra del sol”] <SB, Poetry>

tossups.question: 23. A man with this surname suggests that a bank’s investigating committee moved several photographs when he is accused by a woman of doing so, after which he begins crying out his own name. That character with this surname discusses “the lie made into the rule of the world” after a priest convinces him that a “cheating” character in a story was himself deceived. Another character with this last name survives by lowering a teaspoon down a well for water and is detained in a prison camp as a (*) “CM.” That character with this last name carries his mother’s ashes in a wheelbarrow to Prince Albert. A character with this surname hears the parable “Before the Law” and dies “like a dog” after being accused of an unknown crime. For 10 points, name this last initial of the harelipped gardener Michael created by J. M. Coetzee, as well as Josef, the protagonist of The Trial.
tossups.answer: K. [accept Michael K. or Josef K.] <JC, LongFic>

tossups.question: 24. This city is home to the oldest prison in the U.S., the notorious Ash Street Jail. A major 1958 volcanic eruption in the Azores triggered the second wave of mass Portuguese migration to this city, helping cement it as the “Portuguese capital of America.” Wamsutta Mills was a major center of this city’s textile industry, which was affected by a 1928 strike organized by the Communist Party. It was called the “fugitive’s Gibraltar” for hosting many escaped slaves, including Box Brown and Frederick Douglass. This city became known as (*) “The City that Lit the World” in the mid-19th century because, thanks to its deeper natural harbor, it supplanted Nantucket as the hub of the industry that supplied most of America’s heating oil, as well as spermaceti and other products. For 10 points, name this city in southern Massachusetts that was historically the most important whaling port in the U.S.
tossups.answer: New Bedford <WA, US History>
